title: RUTH SUNDERLAND: The high price of a No Deal Brexit
text:
Warnings about the economic damage that will be created by an increasingly likely No Deal Brexit are coming thick and fast.

In its worst-case scenario, the Bank of England envisages a fall in GDP of 5.5 per cent, a rise in unemployment to 7 per cent and inflation hitting 5.25 per cent.

Even in that dire situation, the financial system could cope, as the Bank made clear yesterday. That is comforting, but only up to a point. There is still likely to be turmoil on stock and bond markets and the already enfeebled currency will be hit hard.

No Deal threat: In its worst-case scenario, the Bank of England envisages a fall in GDP of 5.5 per cent, a rise in unemployment to 7 per cent and inflation hitting 5.25 per cent

Kristalina Georgieva, the new head of the IMF, says any kind of Brexit will be 'painful', particularly as it coincides with a 'synchronised slowdown' around the world, with a slump in global manufacturing and trade tensions running high.

For its part, the Institute for Fiscal Studies' (IFS) annual Green Budget a couple of days ago was a sobering read.

Boris Johnson and Chancellor Sajid Javid have already set out their stall for an election with promises of lavish spending on the NHS, law and order and education.

Carrots have been dangled in the shape of tax cuts, such as a proposal to take 2.5m people out of the higher rate tax bracket.

Problem is, a No Deal Brexit that would strain the public purse strings is neither wise nor sustainable. The IFS reckons it would push up Government debt to its highest level for 50 years.

Borrowing could balloon up to £100billion, or 4 per cent of national income, busting right through the Government's own fiscal mandate.

A No Deal Brexit would mean two years of zero growth, followed by low growth.

Any forecaster can be wrong. The IFS, however, isn't a politicised fear-monger, but a highly respected body with a reputation for independence and integrity.

Brexit is not just about the economy. It is about sovereignty and self-determination, which many Leave voters will consider more important.

In the long term, the UK can certainly prosper outside the EU. But let's not pretend there is no price to be paid for No Deal.

Leap of faith

The move by John and Irene Hays, the north-eastern couple who own Hays Travel, to buy 555 of Thomas Cook's stores, saving 2,500 jobs is a bold one.

It is a leap of faith to take on so many bricks-and-mortar shops at a time when more people are booking their holidays online.

John Hays reckons he and Irene can succeed because they are independent, offering holidays from across the market.

They sound like good sorts – when their sales hit £1billion, the couple – who own the firm between them – shared out £1million among their staff. However, they are obviously hard-nosed business people too.

The sum they paid for the shops has not been disclosed but they are bound to have got a knockdown price.

From their point of view, it was an opportunity to swoop in and take their own business to a different level at a stroke.

The Thomas Cook chain that they have bought is bigger than their existing operations: currently they have just 190 shops and 1,900 staff.

The risk is that the takeover and the work involved in the integration proves to be overwhelming. Even so, it is a welcome show of confidence in the beleaguered British High Street.

Wrong number

BT'S revamp of its 615 stores so that its brand will return to shop fronts for the first time in 17 years is also a boost for the High Street.

Under its new boss Philip Jansen, the company recognises it has to improve customer service, which has too often been awful.

Behind all of this is the need to move to ultrafast broadband – a key element of Boris's election sales pitch – to improve people's lives, help small firms sell to a wider range of customers and to improve the country's woeful productivity performance.

The company has some sensible plans, including a team of 900 home tech experts, and bringing all of its customer call centres back to the UK and Ireland by January, a year earlier than planned.

It's just a shame that, as my colleagues on Money Mail have discovered, BT has been operating a bonkers policy on call centres, in effect offering two-tier service levels.

Only customers paying extra for a premium broadband package, starting at more than £60 a month, are guaranteed to be put through to a call centre in the UK or Ireland when they have a problem.

For a company with 'British' in its name, that's quite an own goal.
